content.html:
By setting the colour of the text, you can no longer tell if a widget is locked or not. In Windows, the text was black by default, so it must be OS/theme related.

I think that we should extend the default css to the following (feel free to alter the colours, but these looked reasonable to me, also, my tabs/spacing may not be consistent, as I was editing in BLACS)

DigitalOutput {
    font-size: 12px;
    background-color: rgb(20,75,20,192);
    border: 1px solid rgb(20,75,20,128);
    border-radius: 3px;
    padding: 2px;
    color: #202020;
}

DigitalOutput:hover {
    background-color: #148214;
    border: None;
}

DigitalOutput:disabled{
   background-color: rgb(20,75,20,120);
   color: #505050;
}

DigitalOutput:checked {
    background-color: qlineargradient(x1: 0, y1: 0, x2: 0, y2: 1,
                                      stop: 0 #48dd48, stop: 1 #20ff20);
    border: 1px solid #8f8f91;
    color: #000000;
}

DigitalOutput:hover:checked {
    background-color: qlineargradient(x1: 0, y1: 0, x2: 0, y2: 1,
                                      stop: 0 #48dd48, stop: 1 #78ff78);
    border: 1px solid #8f8f91;
}

DigitalOutput:checked:disabled{
   background-color: qlineargradient(x1: 0, y1: 0, x2: 0, y2: 1,
                                      stop: 0 #7ee77e, stop: 1 #62ff62);
   color: #606060;
}

content.raw:
I think it's good to add a default stylesheet. However, by inserting the stylesheet this way, we lose the ability to ever do this again (as in, it's going to be a pain to detect they are using the default stylesheet, and so we shouldn't feel bad about forcing a change on them).

I do however think that when they view the theme preferences, what we're calling the default stylesheet should show up, I guess it just doesn't need to be saved in the BLACS preferences HDF5 file unless it is changed. That way we'll always know that if the stored stylesheet is `''`, we use the default one (and thus when we make changes to the default one, people will get those changes).

Does that make sense?

That way we'll always know that if the stored stylesheet is '', we use the default one (and thus when we make changes to the default one, people will get those changes).

Does that make sense?

content.html:
Nope! The comparison strips all whitespace:

def is_default_stylesheet(stylesheet):
    """Return whether a stylesheet is the same as the default stylesheet, modulo whitespace"""

    def no_whitespace(s):
        return "".join(s.split())

    return no_whitespace(str(stylesheet)) == no_whitespace(DEFAULT_STYLESHEET)
